headline: Trump vs Intel, tariffs go into effect, Apple investment: 3 Things
summary: Here are some of the stories Wall Street is watching on Thursday, Aug. 7. President Trump is calling for Intel (INTC) CEO Lip-Bu Tan to resign "immediately," saying he is "highly conflicted." Most of Trump's reciprocal tariffs went into effect at midnight. Apple (AAPL) will invest $100 billion in the US. Trump has been pressuring the company to build its iPhones in the US. To watch more expert insights and analysis on the latest market action, check out more Morning Brief.

headline: Coherent and Apple Expand Strategic Partnership With New Multiyear VCSEL Agreement in Texas
summary: SAXONBURG, Pa., Aug. 07, 2025 (GLOBE NEWSWIRE) -- Coherent Corp. (NYSE: COHR), a global leader in photonics, announced that it has entered a new multiyear strategic supply agreement with Apple, expanding their long-standing partnership. Under the new agreement, Coherent will continue to produce vertical-cavity surface-emitting lasers (VCSELs) that enable key features such as Face ID on iPhone and iPad devices shipped around the world. headline: Tariffs hit, Apple rises
summary: What matters in U.S. and global markets today By Mike Dolan, Editor-At-Large, Finance and Markets Wall Street and global stocks rose on Thursday, as Apple's domestic investment push, dovish noises on interest rates and a generally upbeat earnings season trumped chip stock hits and the arrival of the U.S. tariff day. The day's diary is topped by a likely Bank of England interest rate cut and U.S. weekly jobless numbers that take on unusual importance in light of last week's July payrolls confusion.

headline: Wall St eyes higher open as tariff exemption hopes boost tech stocks
summary: (Reuters) -Wall Street's main indexes were poised for a strong start on Thursday, buoyed by optimism that major technology companies could avoid U.S. President Donald Trump's latest tariffs on chip imports.  Apple's  shares climbed 2.8% in premarket trading, having risen 5.1% and led gains on Wall Street in the prior session, after Trump said the iPhone maker will invest an additional $100 billion in the U.S., bringing its total commitment to $600 billion over the next four years.  Trump also announced a tariff of about 100% on imports of semiconductors but said it would not apply to companies that are manufacturing in the U.S. or have committed to do so.

raw.headline: Wall St eyes higher open as tariff exemption hopes boost tech stocks
raw.summary: (Reuters) -Wall Street's main indexes were poised for a strong start on Thursday, buoyed by optimism that major technology companies could avoid U.S. President Donald Trump's latest tariffs on chip imports.  Apple's  shares climbed 2.8% in premarket trading, having risen 5.1% and led gains on Wall Street in the prior session, after Trump said the iPhone maker will invest an additional $100 billion in the U.S., bringing its total commitment to $600 billion over the next four years.  Trump also announced a tariff of about 100% on imports of semiconductors but said it would not apply to companies that are manufacturing in the U.S. or have committed to do so.
